page.title: 01THE NORTH CERNEY AREA
page.content: Our block lies in the Cotswolds on either side of the main A435 Cirencester - Cheltenham road. The road follows the valley of the River Churn which is the main geographical feature of the block. To the east, the land rises to North Cerney Downs which are about 200 metres above sea level. To the west, the land rises to a narrow plateau and then drops steeply towards the Cirencester - Gloucester road (A417 - the Roman Ermine Street). The valley itself is used for rough grazing since the sides are too steep and the valley bottom too wet for anything else. The Downs are used for growing cereal crops. There are three small villages: North Cerney, Rendcomb and Woodmancote, mostly built of Cotswold stone . There is a big chain of pylons going north/south across our block carrying electricity cables.
